Description: An introduction to the Russian language in the context of Russian cultures.
A continuation of the introduction to the Russian language in the context of Russian cultures.

Reinforces material presented in Elementary Russian I (RUSS 12201). Must be taken with Elementary Russian
I.

Reinforces material presented in Elementary Russian II (RUSS 12202). Must be taken together with
Elementary Russian II.
Continued development of speaking, listening, reading and writing skills using a variety of cultural materials.
Continuation of RUSS 22201.

Reinforces material presented in Intermediate Russian I (RUSS 22201). Must be taken together with
Intermediate Russian I.

Reinforces material presented in Intermediate Russian II (RUSS 22202). Must be taken with Intermediate
Russian II.
A systematic approach to Russian grammar and syntax.
Introduction to advanced oral and written discourse strategies in Russian.

Study of the Russian sound system with special emphasis on pronunciation and intonation. Application of the
international phonetic alphabet to Russian.

Translation practice with Russian texts using principles and techniques learned in the lecture class. To be
taken concurrently with TRST 30230.

Course Name: CONVERSATION FOR BUSINESS AND SPECIAL PURPOSES:RUSSIAN
Description:
Introduction to the special vocabulary of business and other special subject areas; introduces the concept of
language for special purposes and emphasizes the use of special vocabulary in conversations in business and
other settings.
Reading and analysis of modern Russian plays and stories.
Reading and analysis of major poems and introduction to folklore.
A survey of Russian history and intellectual life.

This course is designed as a survey of major authors, movements and works of nineteenth and twentieth
century Russian literature in English translation. No knowledge of Russian required.

Course Name: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN RUSSIAN LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Workshops individually designed to provide instruction and training in specific areas of
Russian studies.

Course Name: SPECIAL TOPICS IN RUSSIAN LANGUAGE AND LITERATURES
Description: (Repeatable for credit when topic varies)Topic to be announced in schedule of classes.

Prerequisites: 6hours of upper-division Russian (RUSS) courses and special approval of the department chairperson.
Description: (Repeatable for credit)Independent investigation of problems in Russian language or literature.
A continuation of RUSS 32211.

Theory and practice course that discusses translation theory and emphasizes Russian-to-English translation of
selected texts in business, technology, medicine and law.

Survey of the typical text types of business in the Russian culture and language. Practice sessions focus on
reading and understanding specialized texts and on the translation and composition of selected special texts in
Russian.

Course Name: SURVEY OF RUSSIAN AND SOVIET LITERATURE
Description:
Introduces students to the major movements and authors of Russian, Soviet and post-Soviet literature
beginning with Karamizin and ending with Boris Akunin.

Course Name: RESEARCH PROJECT IN RUSSIAN LANGUAGE AND LITERATURE
Prerequisites: 6 hours of 40000-level Russian (RUSS) courses and specialapproval.
Description: Thesis or other independent study.
Advanced practice in written and oral expression in Russian.
Students apply linguistic and communication science concepts to case studies of language mediation.
(Repeatable for credit when topic varies)Topic announced in schedule of classes.

Prerequisites: Graduate standing and departmental special approval.
Description:
(Repeatable for credit)Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students. Credits earned
applied toward degree requirements if department approves repeat registration permitted.

Translation of documents from a variety of literary and cultural sources, including literature, expository and
journalistic prose, scholarly treaties and essays. Translation into Russian will also be emphasized.

An introduction to methods and resources for the translation of commercial, economic, financial, legal,
diplomatic and governmental documents.

An introduction to methods and resource for the translation of scientific, technical, industrial and medical
documents.

Students will be responsible for a major translation and a terminology glossary as well as a critical analysis of
the source text, the problems encountered during the translation process and the strategies used to solve
them.
